Graphical abstract Two-stage gasification-reforming (TSGR) promotes the municipal solid waste (MSW) upcycling by separating reforming catalysts and gasifications for a stable MSW utilization and hydrogen generation. As global municipal solid waste (MSW) quantities continue to escalate, serious socio-environmental challenges arise, necessitating innovative solutions. Waste-to-hydrogen (WTH) via two-stage gasification-reforming (TSGR) presents an emergent technology for MSW upcycling, offering to ease waste management burdens and bolster the burgeoning hydrogen economy. Despite early initiatives to advance TSGR technology, a cohesive and critical analysis of cutting-edge knowledge and strategies to enhance hydrogen production remains lacking. This review aggregates literature on MSW upcycling to hydrogen via TSGR, with a focus on optimizing process control and catalytic efficiency. It underscores technological avenues to augment hydrogen output, curtail catalyst costs, and refine system performance. Particularly, the review illuminates the potential for integrating chemical and calcium looping into TSGR processes, identifying opportunities, and pinpointing challenges. The review concludes with a summary of the current state of techno-economic analysis for this technology, presenting outstanding challenges and future research directions, with the ultimate goal of transitioning WTH from theoretical to practical application. Keywords Municipal solid waste Upcycling Gasification Reforming Hydrogen 1 Introduction Annually, the world generates over 2.2 billion tonnes of municipal solid waste (MSW), a figure projected to reach 3.9 billion by 2050 [1]. The composition of MSW differs by region which is categorized into four groups based on its content: recyclable, kitchen, hazardous, and miscellaneous waste. Its primary components include plastics, rubber, kitchen scraps, paper, textiles, biomass residue, ceramics, glass, and metal. In the six coastal cities of eastern China, kitchen waste constitutes over 50% of the overall MSW. In comparison to other developed nations, kitchen waste represents a minor portion of MSW components, while paper and plastic waste make up significant proportions. For example, the food waste content was 41.9%, 31.5%, and 27.2% in Singapore, Tokyo, and Berlin, respectively [2]. Landfilling, the traditional method for municipal solid waste disposal, poses significant risks to both the environment and public health. Moreover, this method neglects the recovery of inherent energy within MSW, leading to a loss of valuable resources. Incineration serves as a prevalent alternative to landfilling for municipal solid waste (MSW), facilitating the conversion of waste into energy and offering a more resource-efficient solution. For example, more than 70% of MSW is processed through waste-to-energy plants due to the limited space for landfill in Japan, while up to 50% of MSW in the UK is processed by waste-to-energy facilities [3]. However, current incineration technologies also come with significant drawbacks [4]. Specifically, the combustion of MSW suffers from low energy efficiency (20%–32%) [5], produces toxic pollutants such as dioxins [6], and as a result, develops poor public perceptions. Therefore, there is an urgent need for the development of novel MSW management technologies. Advanced thermal chemical conversion technologies can be used to upcycle MSW into high-value fuels, chemicals, and materials with a high process efficiency and a low carbon footprint, which gives it immense potential as an ideal solution for the disposal of MSW [7,8]. Furthermore, these thermal conversion of MSW can produce other valuable products (such as slag and recyclable metals) for a more sustainable vision, such as converting ash into reusable slag [9–11]. The ability to upcycle MSW into H2 is particularly significant for achieving a green and sustainable economy [12]. The global H2 demand production reached almost 95 Mt in 2022, while the low-emission H2 production was less than 1 Mt (0.7% of global production), leaving a huge “green hydrogen gap” [13]. However, direct gasification of MSW by air, oxygen, or steam normally produces gases with limited H2 yield. To enhance the production of H2, the gasification processes can be integrated with the catalytic steam reforming of the derived volatiles, i.e., tar and non-condensable hydrocarbons (Fig. 1 ). It is estimated that approximately 38% of global H2 demand by 2030 will be met if 20% of the MSW is converted into H2 worldwide, which can help to fill the “green hydrogen gap” significantly. Coupling MSW gasification and catalytic steam reforming can be achieved in single or two stages. In the two-stage gasification-reforming (TSGR) process, MSW is gasified in the first stage, and the volatiles (non-condensable organics and tar) are catalytically reformed by steam in the second stage. The reforming reaction is typically coupled with the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, i.e., the reaction between CO and H2O, to generate more H2. Compared to single-stage MSW gasification-reforming, the TSGR process has been reported as a preferred option due to a number of advantages, such as good separation between waste residue and catalysts, flexible temperature control of two stages, and enhanced process efficiency (Fig. 1) [14]. Moreover, the TSGR process can be readily combined with other processes, such as chemical looping [15] and calcium looping [16,17], to further improve the overall process efficiency and H2 yield. Despite the potential of the TSGR process in MSW upcycling to H2, there are significant industrial-scale challenges to overcome. These include process efficiency enhancement, reactor design, system integration, catalyst development, and the handling of MSW complex composition [18–20]. Our review critically examines TSGR technology advancements, focusing on consolidating and contextualizing the factors that constitute the entire technology, as well as analyzing bottlenecks and prospective breakthroughs. The development of ideal catalysts, which are highly active, stable, and cost-effective, remains a critical issue. Novel integrations of TSGR with chemical or calcium looping could significantly improve H2 production. We conclude by summarizing the techno-economic analysis progress, identifying remaining knowledge gaps, and outlining future research directions to transition MSW management toward sustainable upcycling technology. 2 Two-stage gasification-reforming of MSW Gasification of municipal solid waste (MSW) offers a sustainable pathway for thermal degradation, yielding gaseous hydrocarbons, CO, and H2 [7]. This technology is favored over incineration for its flexibility and reduced environmental impact, functioning well even in smaller municipalities. By adjusting gasification parameters, the product output can be effectively modified. Numerous reviews have analyzed MSW gasification, delving into the impact of waste composition, reaction condition optimization, reactor development, product application, and understanding the reaction mechanisms and kinetics [7,21,22]. The H2 concentration in syngas is largely influenced by the MSW composition, with a higher plastic content enhancing H2 levels, whereas biomass contributes more to CO and CO2 production [23,24]. These gaseous products, including CO, H2, CH4, and C2–C4 hydrocarbons, are highly valued for their extensive applicability, high calorific value, and potential for industrial refinement. The volatiles from MSW gasification are primarily composed of H2, CO, CO2, NO x , SO x , organic fractions (i.e., C1–C4, aromatics, and tar) and inorganic components (i.e., particles and salts) [25–28]. Particularly, the organic fractions can undergo steam reforming to produce H2 and CO, which resembles the process of industrial steam methane reforming (SMR). This reaction is typically succeeded by the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, i.e., the reaction between CO and H2O to produce more H2 and CO2, thereby improving the H2 yield and concentration. Various process parameters such as temperature, sample-to-catalyst ratio, and steam flow rate have been investigated to understand their impact on the reforming process. Owing to the endothermic nature of steam reforming reactions, they are promoted at higher temperatures. Zhang et al. reported an increase in H2 production from 8.05 to 18.02 mmol g−1 tyre as the catalysis temperature increased from 700 to 900 °C [29]. Blanco et al. investigated the effects of temperature on tar composition from the TSGR of refuse-derived fuel (RDF) and found the optimal parameters for H2 production (approximately 27 mmol g−1) at a reforming temperature of 900 °C with a sample-to-catalyst ratio of 1:2 [30]. Furthermore, it was discovered that increasing the steam flow during catalytic reforming can significantly boost H2 production; a steam injection rate of 5 g h−1 increased the H2 yield to roughly 35 mmol g−1 [29]. 3 Catalyst developments for the TGSR A suitable catalyst is pivotal for lowering the activation energy in the catalytic reforming of products from MSW gasification, thereby enriching the H2 concentration. The catalysts suitable for catalytic reforming in MSW applications should consider the complexity of the waste-derived syngas, the presence of impurities, the poisoning, and the mitigation approaches [31]. Various catalysts have been explored, including non-noble metals like Ni, Fe, Co, and Cu, noble metals such as Ru, Pt, Pd, and Rh [32], as well as mineral catalysts including olivine, with tailored crystal structures, morphologies, and surface areas [33]. Catalyst design research has concentrated on enhancing activity, stability, and cost-effectiveness [34]. 3.1 Catalyst activity in the reforming stage Transition metals are commonly used for the catalytic reforming of volatiles from MSW gasification to produce H2 [35]. The activity and stability of the catalysts are significantly affected by the type of transition metals used. Noble metals, particularly Rh, Ru, Pd, and Pt, show high catalytic reforming activity, with Rh > Pt > Pd > Ru in general effectiveness [36]. However, due to the high cost of noble metals, their usage in catalysts is generally low (<1 wt%), limiting these noble metal-based catalysts to small-scale fundamental studies [37]. Consequently, non-noble metal catalysts, such as those based on Ni, Fe, or Co, are more extensively researched for steam reforming due to their lower cost [38,39]. Ni-based catalysts are particularly prevalent, known for their strong C–C and C–H bond cleavage activity [20,40,41]. Fe and Cu are less favored; Fe is active only for C–C cleavage, and Cu for C–H cleavage [42]. In TSGR studies of cellulose, Ni demonstrated the highest activity, followed by Pt, Pd, Co, Fe, and Cu [43]. While metallic forms are commonly the active phase in catalysts, structures such as spinel-type (NiAlO4 or CuFe2O4) and perovskite-type (LaNiO3 or LaFeO3) have also been effective in enhancing H2 production [42]. Bimetallic catalysts have piqued interest for their unique properties, differing from monometallic catalysts. For example, with a Ni-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, an impressive H2 yield of 93 mmol H2 g−1 was obtained from plastic waste. Additionally, integrating noble metals, such as Ru and Pt, into Ni-based catalysts has markedly improved H2 production [32]. Promoters are often introduced to enhance the activity of Ni-based catalysts; for instance, La2O3 being added to Ni/Al2O3 has remarkably improved both the conversion (>99%) and H2 production (by 35%) during continuous TSGR of polypropylene (PP) (Fig. 2 b) [44]. Furthermore, catalyst support plays a key role in enhancing the dispersion of catalytic sites. Typically, the active metals are introduced in the support materials via impregnation [20], co-precipitation [39], or sol-gel methods [45]. A good support should have a large surface area, appropriate pore size, and good thermal stability. The commonly used supports are Al2O3 [32], SiO2 [46], ZrO2 [20], CeO2 [47], and zeolites [48]. Al2O3 is an excellent support due to its high thermal stability, large surface area, and good mechanical strength [32]. It has been reported that the Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by co-precipitation could produce more H2 compared to the impregnation-derived counterpart, which was likely due to better metal dispersion and higher thermal stability [18]. Zeolites are crystalline alumina-silicates with a well-defined microporous structure and uniform pore size. Ni/ZSM-5 could promote catalytic steam reforming to enhance H2 production due to the micro-mesoporosity of ZSM-5, which enhances reactant-catalyst interaction. The catalytic activity for Ni on different types of zeolites was found to be Ni/ZSM-5 > Ni/β-zeolite > Ni/Y-zeolite, with the H2 yield being 66, 61, and 58 mmol g−1 feedstock, respectively. Interestingly, it was also found that the composition of the ZSM-5 zeolite had a notable effect on the catalytic activity of the Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst. For example, Ni/ZSM-5 with a low Si/Al ratio of 30 produced a higher amount of H2 compared that with high Si/Al ratios [48]. 3.2 Catalyst stability in the reforming stage Catalyst deactivation is a common issue for the application of catalysts in the second stage of gasification-reforming of MSW. The reasons include sintering of metals, oxidation of metals, support degradation, and coke deposition [49], among which the catalyst sintering and coke deposition are the most crucial reasons [18]. Sintering of metals can occur at elevated temperatures, resulting in the significant loss of active sites. This is typically caused by (i) migration of atoms adsorbed on smaller particles (adatoms) to enlarge metal particles, known as Ostwald ripening and (ii) coalescence of small particles to form large particles [49]. Enabled by in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM), it is suggested that the early stage of Ni sintering is the Ostwald ripening of small particles, while in the later stage of sintering, the particle coalescence dominates [50]. The main factor of sintering is the reaction temperature of the reforming process, because the migration of metals starts to occur when the temperature exceeds the Tamman temperature (half of the melting point) [51]. Noble metals show higher sintering resistance due to their higher Tamman temperatures (Ru, 1089 °C; Rh, 856 °C; Pt, 741 °C; Pd, 641 °C) [52]. However, the Tamman temperature of Ni is only 590 °C [52], indicating a high sintering possibility in the reforming process (typically higher than 700 °C) [18]. For example, it was observed that the sintering rate of Ni was 20 nm h−1 at 700 °C during catalytic reforming reaction [53]. Several methods can help to minimize metal sintering. For example, Ir or Rh can be added to Ni-based catalysts to stabilize Ni nanoparticles via the formation of alloys [54]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations suggest that nickel (Ni) atoms exhibit equal stability in both the first and the second surface layer of iridium (Ir) and rhodium (Rh). This results in a synergistic effect when Ni is alloyed with either Ir or Rh, effectively preserving a larger active metal surface area. Strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) can also help to prevent sintering due to the stabilization effect of the support on the transition metals. For example, perovskite-type catalysts (e.g., LaNi x Co1− x O3 and La1− x Ce x Ni0.8Fe0.2O3) exhibit SMSI, which perform better sintering resistance during the steam reforming process at 650 °C [55,56]. In recent years, some novel structures have been developed to further improve the stability of the catalysts. These, for example, include mesoporous silica with homogeneous pore structures (such as MCM-41 and SBA-15) which prevent pore plugging by metal particles (Fig. 3 a) [57], core-shell structures in which the metal catalysts are encapsulated by a support overlayer, such as SiO2, Al2O3, MgO, ZrO2, and TiO2 (Fig. 3b) [58], nanotubes, such as CNTs, with transition metal nanoparticles loaded within their channels (Fig. 3c) [59], and lamellar or layered structures of supported catalysts, where the transition metal are confined in the layers of the support (Fig. 3d) [60]. All of these structures are designed to separate and stabilize transition metal nanoparticles using a sintering-resistant support, thereby preventing the aggregation of the transition metals. Another important factor that leads to catalyst deactivation is the masking of active sites by coke deposition [61]. This step is initiated by (i) the adsorption of carbon layers (carbide formation), (ii) encapsulation of the active sites, followed by (iii) blockage of the pores of the support, and (iv) degradation of the catalyst structure (Fig. 3e) [49]. CO disproportionation and hydrocarbon decomposition/cracking are the two mechanisms proposed for the formation of coke/carbon. CO disproportionation mainly happens at low temperatures (≤500 °C), while hydrocarbon cracking is the dominant reason in steam reforming at high temperatures (≥700 °C) [62]. Steam reforming happens during the decomposition of heavy hydrocarbons into light hydrocarbons, and these intermediates act as precursors of coke [49]. Some works had also explored the evolution of coke on the surface of the catalyst (Fig. 3f). Specifically, coke is first formed on both metal particles (Coke I) and the support (Coke II). With the time on stream (TOS), the metal particles are encapsulated by the coke and sintered, and thus Coke I is inhibited, and Coke II is promoted [63]. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) are utilized to study coke deposition on catalysts. TGA reveals that layered carbons are oxidized at lower temperatures, while filamentous carbons show higher oxidation peaks [64], corroborated by SEM findings. During the TSGR of plastics, PP and polyethylene (PE) predominantly form layered carbons, whereas polystyrene (PS) tends to produce more filamentous carbons [65]. Initially, PS mainly yields aromatics, while PP and PE produce alkanes and alkenes, leading to heavier products advancing to the second stage of TSGR in PS, thereby generating more layered carbons. This abundance of layered carbons accelerates catalyst deactivation in the TSGR of PS. Additionally, Raman spectroscopy identifies the presence of structural defects and graphitic carbon in coke through D and G bands, respectively [66]. The concentration of steam affects the Ni species on the catalyst surface, impacting the rate of carbon graphitization and consequently the nature of carbon deposits. Higher water levels promote coke gasification and decrease polymer carbon formation, reducing graphitization [67]. The nature of supports can also significantly affect the generation of carbon deposits. The Brønsted acidic sites have been proven to be the reason for the coke formation via catalyzing the cracking and polymerization of the organics [68]. Therefore, the supports with abundant acidic sites, such as Al2O3 and zeolites, are more intent to form coke on the surface of the catalysts [48,69]. In contrast, the supports with redox properties (e.g., CeO2) can supply lattice oxygen for the in-situ oxidation of the coke and its precursor CO, easing the coke deposition on the catalyst surface [49]. To further improve the ability of catalysts to prevent coke formation, promoters are usually introduced. Oxides such as (CeO2, MgO, La2O3, and ZrO2) can be added into Ni/Al2O3 catalysts to neutralize the acidity and thus prevent coke deposition [69]. Another approach to deal with catalyst stability is to produce high-value-added carbon materials, instead of prohibiting coke formation on the surface of the catalyst, to enhance the overall process profit. For example, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) can be collected from the coke formation on the Ni-based or Fe-based catalysts [39,70]. As shown in Fig. 4 (a and b), the carbon yields obtained from the TSGR of low-density polyethylene (LDPE), high-density polyethylene (HDPE), PP, general-purpose polystyrene (GPPS), and high-impact polystyrene (HIPS) were 59.4, 64.1, 67.6, 78.0, and 80.9 wt%, respectively; >96% of these were identified as multiwalled CNTs [70]. To this end, other forms of energy, such as microwaves, could also perform impressive performances on yielding CNTs and H2 [71]. Therefore, the unwanted coke from the surface of the catalyst is turned into a valuable by-product CNTs, which can be used in many areas such as purification [72], energy storage [73,74], electrochemical catalysis [75], thermal management [76], medicinal therapy [77], and sensing [78], due to their unique physical and chemical properties. The gases produced from MSW gasification contain impurities such as HCl and sulfur compounds, which can poison catalysts used in the steam reforming process [79]. Notably, even low concentrations (a few ppm) of H2S are known to rapidly deactivate Ni-based reforming catalysts by chemisorbing on metal sites, forming NiS and thus reducing the availability of active sites for steam reforming reactions (Ni + H2S → Ni-S + H2). Attempts to regenerate Ni catalysts contaminated with H2S during catalytic tar reforming at 850 °C have shown that the Ni-S species cannot be fully removed during steam/air regeneration, resulting in only partial recovery of the catalytic activity [80]. The low melting point and high surface mobility of NiS may further accelerate sintering and decrease catalyst activity, while sulfur compounds also increase carbon deposition, further diminishing activity [81]. Moreover, the presence of HCl in syngas has been found to decrease both reforming and WGS activities of Ni catalysts. Studies have noted that reforming activity is significantly inhibited by the chemisorption of HCl on Ni [82]. Further research demonstrated that HCl adversely affects WGS activity during steam reforming, despite naphthalene conversion remaining unaffected; the principal issue attributed to HCl was the sintering of Ni, which leads to activity loss [83]. 4 TSGR integrated with chemical looping Chemical looping is a process that involves the use of a metal oxide as an oxygen carrier (OC) for chemical reactions [84]. The process circulates OCs between a fuel reactor and an air reactor (OC regeneration reactor). In the fuel reactor, the material releases oxygen to oxidize the fuel, and the reduced material is then transferred to the air reactor, where it is reoxidized by air before returning to the fuel reactor, thus ‘looping’ continuously [85,86]. Normally, the OCs do not need to be pre-reduced, as the chosen OCs could be in-situ reduced in chemical looping process. Differently, the catalysts applied in abovementioned reforming process need to be activated by H2 or CH4 in advance. MSW gasification can be integrated with chemical looping, known as chemical looping gasification (CLG), using the OC as the gasification agent (Fig. 5 a). However, the separation of the OC from the gasification residue (char) is challenging. To avoid this problem, the reforming process can also be integrated with chemical looping (Fig. 5b), i.e, the chemical looping reforming (CLR) [85]. CLR is the combination of partial oxidation by lattice oxygen and steam reforming of volatiles. The partial oxidation is exothermic, while the steam reforming is endothermic. The combined process could be potentially kept in an exothermic status by tuning the fraction of partial oxidation and steam reforming, which is one main advantage compared to conventional steam reforming reactions [87]. 4.1 Oxygen carrier materials for TSGR integrated with chemical looping One of the main challenges of chemical looping technology is the development of OCs, which are typically metal oxides or supported metal oxides. The ideal OCs should have a high oxygen capacity, fast reaction kinetics, high stability, and low cost [85,88]. The investigated OCs include the oxides of Fe, Ni, Cu, Mn, and Co [89,90]. Further decreasing the cost of OCs and prolonging the stability would push forward the development of integration of TSGR and chemical looping. Waste sourced OCs were recently proposed to achieve “treating waste with waste”, representing a promising and sustainable technology [91–93]. Fe-based materials have been widely studied due to their low cost and environmental compatibility. However, traditional Fe-based OCs have low activity, and the most widely used method is the introduction of another metal, such as Ca [94], Ba [95], Co [52], Ni [96], and Cu [97], to the Fe-based materials. Amongst these metals, Ca is particularly attractive due to the abundance and its ability to improve syngas quality [94]. More specifically, CaO not only acts as the support of OCs, but also provides catalytic sites enhancing tar cracking [98]. For example, the combination of CaO and Fe2O3 was effective for the CLG above 850 °C [99], and the optimal Fe/Ca ratio of 1:1 gave the highest H2 yield [100]. It should be noted that CaO does not act a sorbent here, because CO2 is not captured at this high temperature (>850 °C). The preparation methods of CaO-promoted Fe2O3 also affect chemical looping performance, as CaFe2O4 showed higher activity compared to a physical mixture of CaO and Fe2O3 above 900 °C [101]. Apart from acting as catalysts in catalyzing steam reforming, Ni/NiO has also been widely studied as an OC for chemical looping due to its excellent redox ability. In fact, it has been reported that NiO was the most active OC followed by CuO, Mn2O3, and Fe2O3 [102]. The main reactions in the fuel reactor (reforming reactor) are Volatiles + NiO → CO + H2 + Ni Volatiles + H2O → CO + H2 CO + H2O → H2 + CO2 The main reaction in the air reactor (OC regeneration reactor) is Ni + 1/2O2 → NiO Similar to catalytic steam reforming, one of the major issues of chemical looping is the deactivation of the OCs after multiple cycles caused by carbon deposition. Several methods have been developed to prevent carbon deposition on the surface of OCs, including the selection of suitable supports, improvement of the synthesis methods, and the introduction of an oxidizing atmosphere. For example, NiO/MgAl2O4 was found to exhibit higher activity and lower carbon deposition compared to NiO/NiAl2O4 [103]. OC synthesized from dry impregnation showed lower carbon formation compared to that from deposition-precipitation [104]. Steam could also help to remove carbon deposition, due to the reaction between carbon and steam [105]. 4.2 Process optimization of TSGR integrated with chemical looping Temperature is a key factor in TSGR integrated with chemical looping processes. In the CLG of cellulose solid waste with Ca-Fe-based OCs, the carbon conversion efficiency increased by over 25% from 800 to 950 °C [88]. CLR with Fe-based OC in a bubbling fluidized bed (BFB) has been simulated using computational fluid dynamics (CFD), which included the multi-fluid model and chemical reaction models involving the gasification and the reactions between the vapor phase and OCs. The simulations revealed that the gas yield and gasification efficiency as well as the concentration of H2 and CO increased with the increase of temperature because of the promotion of temperature on the endothermic reaction [106]. Another crucial aspect to consider is the optimization of the OC/fuel ratio and the steam/fuel ratio, as these proportions are pivotal for the system efficiency. The introduction of steam could promote the gas yield, gasification efficiency, and H2 concentration significantly from the CFD simulation with Fe-based OC in a BFB [106]. The increase of fuel feeding rate led to high gasification efficiency but a lower carbon conversion [106]. In the CLG of cellulose solid waste with Ca-Fe bimetallic OC, the optimal OC/fuel and steam/fuel mass ratios were found to be 0.5 and 1.2, respectively [88]. However, in the CLG of pine wood and PE with Fe2O3 as the OC, the optimal product distribution was found at Fe2O3/fuel ratio of 0.25 and steam/fuel mass ratio of 0.25 [107]. Therefore, the optimal OC/fuel and steam/fuel ratios depend on the fuel properties, the OCs, and the type of the reactors. One of the major issues with using MSW for thermochemical conversion is the high chlorine content, which will lead to the formation of polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and dibenzofurans (PCDD/Fs) during MSW combustion [6]. Huang and co-workers found that loading alkali metals and alkaline earth metals on the iron ore OC could facilitate the removal of chlorine in situ with the formation of chlorides, and in turn, reduce organic chlorine pollutants. The effect of metal addition on the formation of corresponding chlorides followed the order of K > Na > Ca [108]. This finding highlighted another advantage of chlorine fixation by using OCs in the thermochemical treatment process of MSW. 5 TSGR integrated with calcium looping CaO-based materials can be used to capture CO2, and the formed CaCO3 can be converted into CaO through high-temperature calcination [109]. The whole process is also called calcium looping. Adding CaO can increase H2 concentration by removing CO2 from syngas and thus promoting MSW gasification or steam reforming due to the Le Chatelier’s principle [85]. Therefore, incorporating CaO-based materials into MSW TSGR process significantly benefits H2 production by lowering the cost of H2 separation [110]. An additional benefit that comes with integrating TSGR with calcium looping is reflected in allowing the carbon in MSW to be captured, which significantly reduces carbon emissions and enhances the sustainability of the overall approach. In the TSGR integrated with a calcium looping system, CaO can be added into the first stage (MSW gasification) or the second stage (steam reforming), as shown in Fig. 6 . In a typical calcium looping integrated with the MSW gasification process, CaO is added to the gasifier to capture CO2 (Fig. 6a). The saturated CaO in the form of CaCO3 is then transferred to a separate reactor for regeneration, producing CO2 and regenerated CaO, which is recycled back to the gasifier. A fraction of sorbents needs to be purged out of the system, and fresh sorbent is added to the gasifier to maintain the CO2 capture activities. Though the addition of CaO promotes MSW gasification significantly, it suffers from the separation of sorbent from gasification residue (char). Therefore, CaO can also be introduced in the second stage to promote the catalytic steam reforming (Fig. 6b) [111]. It should be noted that both scenarios have challenges in terms of sorbent deactivation and high energy input for sorbent regeneration. 5.1 Sorbent materials for TSGR integrated with calcium looping The CaO-based materials may deactivate during calcium looping, ascribed to the attrition of materials and, most importantly, the sintering of CaO particles through high-temperature reactions [112]. Currently, the main types of CaO materials that are studied for calcium looping includes raw CaO, modified CaO, and CaO-containing natural materials. For example, pure CaO was used for promoting the gasification of MSW components (polyethylene, paper pulp, and bamboo) in a fixed-bed reaction system [113]. The addition of CaO significantly benefited H2 production with the consumption of hydrocarbons including CH4. To further enhance the performance of calcium looping enhanced TSGR, sorbent modification and metal-doping techniques are often used to promote the stability and catalytic activity of the CaO-based materials. For example, the addition of Ni to CaO has been reported to be effective in enhancing H2 production and prohibiting CaO deactivation [114]. However, the sintering of Ni/CaO remains to be a major challenge with this approach. To combat this issue, promoters such as TiO2 [115] and HfO2 [116] have been used to further enhance gasification performance by prohibiting CaO sintering. For example, the addition of TiO2 to Ni/CaO increased H2 concentration from 35.1% to 57.7%, when MSW was gasified in a fixed reactor under a steam-containing gasification atmoshpere [115]. CaO-containing natural materials, such as egg shells [117], olivine [118], dolomite [119], and limestone [120] have been investigated in the MSW TSGR processes to enhance H2 production. Dolomite showed a higher CO2 capture capacity compared to limestone at realistic calcium looping conditions, such as high CO2 concentration and quick transition between calcium looping cycles [119]. In addition, the stability of dolomite is relatively high due to the presence of MgO. The performance of limestone and dolomite on calcium looping could be improved by mechanical grinding to reduce crystallinity and thermal pretreatment to enhance stability [121]. For example, around 5% increase in the diffusion-controlled carbonation was observed for a milled limestone sample compared to an original limestone [122]. This was due to the reduced crystalline of limestone after the milling process. In addition, the poorly crystalline milled limestone favoured the calcination of sorbent demonstrating a fast and complete decarbonation at 900 °C, while the regeneration of raw limestone was slow and incomplete. Although the recrystallisation of CaO during thermal pretreatment, forming a stable structure, can enhance the stability of CaO for calcium looping [123], the annealed sample with a higher crystallinity hampers decarbonation [122]. Another key area of materials development for calcium looping enhanced TSGR is the incorporation of oxygen carriers into CaO to integrate chemical looping and achieve higher overall process efficiency. To achieve this mechanism, a bifunctional sorbent-catalyst material (BSCM) needs to be developed. For example, a combination of chemical looping and calcium looping reforming process was proposed with NiO/dolomite bifunctional materials. NiO acted as the OC, while the dolomite acted as the CO2 sorbent [124]. Another BSCM with Fe2O3 and CaO was proposed by Li and co-workers [125]. They confirmed the key role of Fe2O3 in providing oxygen for gasification, and CaO played two roles in CO2 capture and catalytic tar reforming. However, due to the complexity of gasification reactions, it is not clear about the insights of CaO materials for H2 production, in terms of the contribution from adsorption sites and catalytic sites, as both can promote H2 production. 5.2 Process optimization of TSGR integrated with calcium looping To investigate the effect of calcium looping on MSW gasification and steam reforming, Stonor et al. investigated the addition of sorbent at different positions, using cellulose as a representative [43]. Adding sorbent in the first stage leads to the H2 concentration of 74.5%, while adding sorbent in the second stage gives the H2 concentration as high as 92.5%. These results indicate the synergetic effect of the catalyst and the sorbent during steam reforming and carbon capture. In a typical example regarding the effect of gasification temperature, refuse derived fuel (RDF), which contained apple, vegetables, flour, meat, PS, PE, PP, and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) was studied, and it was found that a higher H2 concentration (up to 28%) was obtained at 900 °C, while only ca. 5% H2 was obtained at 600 °C [126]. Similar results regarding the influence of gasification temperature on H2 yield were demonstrated by Lazzarotto et al. [23], who carried out calcium looping MSW gasification using steam as the gasification agent and reported that the highest H2 yield (104 mol kg−1 MSW) was achieved at 900 °C. However, for the investigated temperatures (800–900 °C), higher temperatures decreased the capacity of CO2 capture of the CaO sorbent due to the thermodynamics of CaO carbonation. The high gasification temperature (>900 °C) can cause severe sorbent sintering and ash agglomeration issues [127,128], affecting the long-term process operation. An optimal gasification temperature of 750 °C was suggested for the highest concentration of H2, when temperatures from 650 to 850 °C have been studied for calcium looping gasification of wet MSW [129]. The authors also found that the highest concentration of H2 (50%) was obtained at a Ca/C ratio of 0.7, when the ratio was screened from 0 to 1.3 [129]. The enhancement of H2 production by adding CaO was due to the promoted steam reforming reaction and WGS reaction (CO + H2O → H2 + CO2) according to Le Chatelier’s principle (CO2 + CaO → CaCO3). In addition, the catalytic effect of CaO on the steam reforming reaction contributed to increased H2 production with the increase of CaO addition [130]. When the amount of CaO is too high (>0.7 Ca/C in this case), H2 yield was reduced, which can be ascribed to the poor heat transfer between reactants and more energy was required for heating CaO. Other conditions also affect MSW gasification integrated with calcium looping. For example, as reported by Hu et al. [129], the optimal moisture content of MSW should be provided for a high concentration of hydrogen by promoting water gas shift reaction and limiting the energy requirement of moisture evaporation. The type of CaO was also investigated for hydrogen production from the absorption-enhanced pyrolysis-gasification of corn stalk [131]. Calcined dolomite promoted the highest yield of H2 production (224 mL g−1 biomass), while calcined calcined limestone produced 170 mL/biomass H2. The poor performance of calcine limestone in terms of hydrogen production was linked to its low capacity for CO2 capture during the gasification process. The authors also claimed that the presence of a significant amount of MgO within the adsorbent promoted hydrogen production through catalytic reactions. 6 Process developments and techno-economic analysis (PD-TEA) of TSGR technologies 6.1 PD-TEA of TSGR MSW TSGR for H2 production is not only affected by the type of catalyst, which has been discussed above, but also influenced by reactor types and reaction conditions. As illustrated in Fig. 7 , the configurations of the reactors include (i) fixed bed gasification combined with fixed bed reforming reaction system (Fig. 7a), (ii) spouted bed gasification combined with fluidized bed reforming reaction system (Fig. 7b), and (iii) screw kiln gasification combined with fixed bed reforming reaction system [14]. Fixed-bed is the most widely used configuration in literature since it is easy to design and operate at a laboratory scale [14]. However, fixed bed reactors have low heat transfer and weak gas-solid contact. Another disadvantage of fixed-bed reactors is that they are expensive to run at a large scale due to their strong need for manpower to ensure operations [132]. Therefore, continuous reactors have been developed to optimize the two-stage process to allow higher feedstock loading. Arregi et al. [44] used a continuous bench-scale spouted bed gasification coupled with fluidized bed steam reforming reaction system for the TSGR of polyolefin waste plastics with the Ni/Al2O3-La2O3 catalyst (Fig. 7b), achieving 37 g H2 production per 100 g of plastic at a feeding rate of 5 g h−1 [44]. Moreover, Wu et al. [133] reported a screw kiln gasification coupled with fixed bed steam reforming continuous reaction system to investigate the production of H2 from PP. Using this setup, the authors reported that ca. 22 g of H2 could be produced from 100 g PP with Ni-Mg-Al catalysts. Over the past decades, advancements in gasifier design, engineering, and construction have increased efficiency and fuel flexibility, making industrial applications viable [134]. ENERKEM technology, for instance, utilizes an advanced thermochemical process to convert waste into renewable methanol and ethanol by producing syngas at 700–750 °C under moderate pressure. Syngas is extracted from the top of the gasifier, separated from the sand, and then undergoes extensive cracking and reforming during the freeboard stage. This critical chemical process transforms organic intermediates into simpler molecules, achieving the desired H2/CO ratio, which is then catalytically converted to liquid methanol and ethanol. The Plasco Gasification & Plasma Refining System employs a three-step process where MSW is first subjected to moving bed pyrolysis, followed by combustion of residue and plasma-assisted tar cracking [135]. Similarly, Advanced Biofuel Solutions Ltd’s RadGas technology combines an oxygen vapor fluidized-bed gasifier with a catalytic chamber, where after drying, the refuse-derived fuel (RDF) produces syngas that undergoes contaminant removal in a plasma converter before methanation [136]. These systems emphasize the importance of the freeboard stage for cracking and reforming syngas, and highlight innovative methods to manage contaminants like hydrocarbons, sulfur, and heavy metals, ultimately improving the sustainability and effectiveness. The TSGR process can also be integrated with anaerobic digestion. Wang et al. introduced a carbon-negative method for producing high-purity H2 from MSW by integrating anaerobic digestion with the TSGR process based on bench-scale experiments [137]. Employing a combination of technologies—anaerobic digestion, pyrolysis, catalytic reforming, water-gas shift, and pressure swing adsorption—the process was tailored for Sweden through comprehensive analysis, including sensitivity assessments, mass and energy balances, and techno-economic and feasibility studies. Optimized conditions yielded 72.2 kg of H2 and a reduction of 701.47 kg in CO2 equivalent emissions per ton of dry MSW. The financial outlook, considering negative emissions as revenue, forecasts a 26% internal rate of return and a payback period of 4.3 years. 6.2 PD-TEA of TSGR integrated with chemical looping Integrating carbon capture, the chemical looping gasification offers a sustainable solution for transforming MSW into H2 without the need for air separation units. According to a modeling work of the CLG process, featuring a continuous MSW feed and employing CuFe2O4 spinel as the OC, operating at 800 °C with a steam-to-municipal solid waste ratio of 1.1 and an oxygen carrier flow of 100 kg h−1, the system successfully recovers 67.85% of the input H as pure H2. This results in an energy efficiency of 57.66%, calculated based on the lower heating value (LHV) of MSW, alongside electricity and H2 production metrics (Fig. 8 a) [138]. The H2 production can be integrated with the downstream synthesis of ammonia and methanol. Based on Aspen Plus modelling, Palone and co-workers conducted the TEA of a novel chemical looping plant configuration for the combined production of ammonia and methanol, utilizing recycled HDPE to improve carbon circularity [139]. The plant produces 174 kg h−1 of methanol and 910 kg h−1 of ammonia, with electricity accounting for 68% of operating costs, followed by maintenance (19%) and insurance (8%) (Fig. 8b). At an electricity cost of €0.03 kWh−1, an oxygen selling price of €0.07 kg−1, and an 8% internal rate of return, the cost of final products was at €0.76 kg−1. The process emits 0.017 kgCO2 kg−1 product, substantially lower than traditional methods (0.24 kgCO2 kg−1 methanol and 1.66 kgCO2 kg−1 ammonia), and has an energy intensity of 36 GJ ton−1 product. Although the final product prices are not yet competitive with traditional processes, they are comparable to those of ammonia from electrolysis and air separation, and methanol from electrolysis and direct air capture. MSW gasification in the TSGR process can be replaced with a novel plasma gasification technology. Xu and co-workers conducted a comparative analysis of two food waste-to-hydrogen processes: plasma gasification and its combination with chemical looping using Aspen Plus simulation [140]. The former demonstrated a H2 yield of 6.47 tons per ton with a cost of 2449.82 USD ton−1, attributed mainly to the significant energy demand of plasma torches. In contrast, integrating chemical looping with plasma gasification was shown to reduce electricity use by generating power from high-temperature gas. Additionally, it achieved greater exergy efficiency at 54.31% compared to 31.44% for standalone plasma gasification and offered better environmental performance, with lower acidification and global warming impacts (Fig. 8c). Chemical looping processes can be designed in different ways, but the most widely used reactor is the fluidized bed due to the good contact between the gas phase and the solid phase as well as the fast heat and mass transfer. The transportation of solid OCs from one reactor to the other reactor is also the advantage of fluidized bed reactors [141]. Currently, the CLG of biomass has been tested at a scale of 25 kW, but the TSGR integrated with chemical looping of MSW has not been demonstrated at a scale beyond the laboratory [142]. Therefore, further development is still needed to overcome the limitation of OCs, process optimization, and TEA, before the scale-up of this technology. 6.3 PD-TEA of TSGR integrated with calcium looping Calcium looping enhanced TSGR has a few key units, including gasification, reforming, sorbent regeneration, and heat exchange. The overall energy efficiency can be enhanced by taking advantage of the heat generated from CaO carbonation and recycled from the CO2 stream. Zhang et al. [143] applied a novel CaO/Ca(OH)2 heat storage unit for calcium looping gasification in a process simulation. The authors found that the heat storage unit re-activated used CaO and enhanced H2 production, and the energy conversion efficiency was increased by 5.1% compared to conventional calcium looping gasification. Furthermore, as simulated by Haaf et al. [144], by installing a new power cycle to utilize the heat of carbonation and excess heat from calciner, the net energy efficiency was improved by more than 5%. Calcium looping gasification was studied for H2 and electricity co-production through Aspen Plus simulation [145]. Simulation results indicated that gasification temperature should be higher than 700 °C and the pressure should be around 12 bar to maximize the system efficiency. The internal rate of return (IRR) and payback period of the system, based on economic data, are calculated as 17.4% and 7.4 years, respectively, and the IRR is sensitive to the variation of H2 selling price and fixed capital investment. The targeted key product of calcium looping gasification also affects the whole system’s performance. Manovic et al. [120] studied system analysis for calcium looping gasification to integrate H2 production, gas turbine combined cycle, and solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC), using waste black liquor as the feedstock. Process modelling demonstrated that calcium looping integrated with H2 production had the highest energy penalty, among the three scenarios, however, having the lowest cost of CO2 avoided (48.8 € t−1 CO2, the capital cost was rescaled using the empirical correlation), while the highest net power efficiency was achieved by the calcium looping integrated with SOFC. The authors also pointed out that the cost of CO2 avoided was significantly affected by the capital requirement of calcium looping, the H2 price, and the natural gas price. Natural minerials are regarded as low-cost CaO-source materials. Santos and Hanak evaluated the feasibility of sorption-enhanced gasification leveraging various materials, including natural limestone, limestone modified with seawater, and dolomite. The modelling analysis using the Gibbs reactor showed that modified limestone led to the highest H2 production efficiency at 50%, outperforming dolomite which had the lowest efficiency at 46%. Furthermore, with the capital costs of each piece of equipment scaled up using a scaling size factor, the economic analysis revealed that using dolomite resulted in the highest H2 production cost of 5.4 € kg−1, as opposed to 5.0 € kg−1 with natural limestone. This difference was also reflected in the cost of CO2 avoided, ranging from 114.9 € t−1 with natural limestone to 130.4 € t−1 with dolomite. Consequently, the research suggests that for new sorbents to be considered viable alternatives for CO2 capture and H2 production, their production costs must be competitive with those of natural limestone [146]. 7 Outlooks and future directions In conclusion, this paper has presented a review and examination of upcycling MSW via TSGR for the production of H2 as a clean fuel. Specifically, TSGR integrated with chemical looping or calcium looping is critically reviewed as a novel H2 production technology from MSW processing. The TSGR of MSW is a promising method for dealing with MSW and producing H2. However, this technology has not been successfully commercialized due to a few challenges, such as the low conversion of tar and volatiles, the low concentration of H2, and the deactivation of the catalysts. Therefore, significant efforts are needed for the development of materials, process integration, techno-economic analysis, life cycle assessment, and large-scale demonstration. Exciting progress has been made on steam reforming catalyst development. However, the search for optimal catalysts that are highly active, selective, and stable continues. Within this context, the main challenge is the deactivation of them caused by sintering or coke deposition, which makes the development of catalysts with long-term stability the key to taking the current technology to the next level. One possible way forward for catalysts is to develop single-atom catalysts (SACs) for catalytic reforming of MSW to maximize atomic efficiency. This would involve not only the development of new materials but also significant research to find ways to prevent sintering and minimize coke deposition at an atomic level. In regards to catalyst development, it is also worth noting that it will be essential to develop pelleted catalysts with good mechanical strength to replace the current powder catalysts that are widely used within the community, since this will be crucial to enable the transformation of the current laboratory-based MSW upcycling technology to industrialization. The co-production of H2 and CNTs is a promising alternative pathway to upcycle waste into wealth, since CNTs are valuable materials with potential applications spanning across a variety of areas but are mostly synthesized from fossil fuels at current. Therefore, with the appropriate catalyst, it is possible that converting MSW into CNTs would bring even more economic value than H2. Currently, this process is still at the beginning stage, which means that ample opportunities remain in catalyst development, process optimization, as well as in product purification, characterizations, and applications. Particularly, the properties of CNTs from this process should be compared with the commercial CNT products to verify the value of this process. Generating power or integrating with other chemical process using MSW are also potential approaches to create revenue, such as combining syngas production with MSW gasification [89,147,148]. Compared to biomass, the nitrogen, sulfur, and chlorine content is typically higher in MSW. These elements may form pollutants or cause the deactivation of the catalysts during the TSGR of MSW. In particular, the chlorine content in MSW (0.5–2.0 wt%) is much higher than that in coal or biomass, which makes the removal of chlorine a unique problem specific to the TSGR of MSW, with little experience to be drawn from the utilization of coal or biomass. A dechlorination process at a low temperature may be necessary to remove chlorine-related compounds before the gasification of MSW. Removing these impurities via adsorption approach by introducing Zn is also effective on purifying the MSW gasified gases [149,150]. In addition, the concentration of heavy metals in MSW is usually much higher than in other solid fuels, and heavy metals will cause significant secondary pollution without proper control. Therefore, the transition and speciation of heavy metals during MSW upcycling also need to be further investigated. Finally, TSGR integrated with chemical looping or calcium looping is a new direction with many advantages. However, most of the current studies still use gaseous fuels (such as syngas or biogas) instead of solid fuels. The utilization of MSW is still challenging due to various MSW compositions, complex processes, and material deactivation. Furthermore, the current studies are limited to the lab-scale performance, while the scale-up of the system may bring some new problems, such as the circulation properties of the materials. Moreover, techno-economic analysis is essential to evaluate the life cycle performance of the novel integrated processes and propose the most feasible economic system. Hui Zhou is an Associate Professor and the Director of the Solid Waste and Carbon Cycle Utilization Research Center at Department of Energy and Power Engineering, Tsinghua University, China. His research primarily focuses on heterogeneous catalysis for the thermochemical conversion of solid waste and renewable carbon resources. He has received the Leading Young Scientist of the Nation and the ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering Lectureship Awards. He has served as the Chair for the International Conference on Carbon Capture Science and Technology in 2023. Currently, he is the Executive Editor for the journal Carbon Capture Science & Technology. Shuzhuang Sun is currently a research associate at Zhengzhou University. He received his BS. degree at Shandong University in 2016, MS. Degree at China University of Petroleum in 2019 and Ph.D degree at Queen’s University Belfast in 2023. His research interests focus on integrated CO2 capture and utilization process and renewable carbon resources utilization. Dr. Sun has published more than 30 peer-reviewed papers with over 800 citations and an H-index of 14. Yikai Xu is a researcher in School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science & Technology, Shanghai, China. He was in. He obtained his B.Sc. degree from East China University of Science and Technology and completed his Ph.D. studies with Prof. Steven. E. J. Bell at Queen’s University Belfast, and then engaged as Leverhulme Early Career Fellow (PI) at Queen’s University Belfast. He currently serves as an Associate Editor for Carbon Capture Science & Technology. His research interests are in the development of surface-accessible nanomaterials for SERS and catalytic applications. Yeshui Zhang is now a Lecturer in School of Engineering at University of Aberdeen, UK. She was a Faraday Institution Research Fellow at University College London, UK since January 2018 .She has completed her BSc. from University of Birmingham in 2012 and MSc. (Engineering) from The University of Sheffield in 2013. She finished her PhD in September 2017 at University of Leeds. Her research interests cover broad area of chemical engineering, including energy storage materials, lithium-ion battery manufacturing, pyrolysis-catalysis of waste, high temperature quartz crystal microbalance, carbon nanotubes synthesis and circular economy of plastics. Shouliang Yi is currently a Principal Research Scientist & Team Lead at U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). He is also NETL Principal Investigator of a number of projects related to NETL's water-energy program. His research is focused on the development of novel membrane- and sorbent-based materials to support the Carbon Capture and Utilization Program (CCUS) and Water Management at NETL. Chunfei Wu is a Reader at the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering and the Chemical Engineering Programme Lead at Queen's University Belfast. He has worked in the areas of converting renewable and waste resources to energy, fuel, and chemicals through catalytic thermo-chemical routes for more than 15 years. He is a Subject Editor for Process Safety and Environmental Protection in the area of waste management, and he is a Charted Scientist and a Member of Royal Society of Chemistry.

coredata.dc:description: As global municipal solid waste (MSW) quantities continue to escalate, serious socio-environmental challenges arise, necessitating innovative solutions. Waste-to-hydrogen (WTH) via two-stage gasification-reforming (TSGR) presents an emergent technology for MSW upcycling, offering to ease waste management burdens and bolster the burgeoning hydrogen economy. Despite early initiatives to advance TSGR technology, a cohesive and critical analysis of cutting-edge knowledge and strategies to enhance hydrogen production remains lacking. This review aggregates literature on MSW upcycling to hydrogen via TSGR, with a focus on optimizing process control and catalytic efficiency. It underscores technological avenues to augment hydrogen output, curtail catalyst costs, and refine system performance. Particularly, the review illuminates the potential for integrating chemical and calcium looping into TSGR processes, identifying opportunities, and pinpointing challenges. The review concludes with a summary of the current state of techno-economic analysis for this technology, presenting outstanding challenges and future research directions, with the ultimate goal of transitioning WTH from theoretical to practical application.
